bibl.title: Letter, Charles Fox near Winchester, Tenn., to Sister 1862 July 27
[Letter] Sunday July 27th 1862 [near Winchester, Tenn. to] Sister
bibl.note: In a letter dated July 27, 1862, Charles Fox, a soldier from Indiana, writes to his sister from camp "within three miles of Winchester, Tenn." Fox tells his sister that he is "very tired of the service and would give anything to get out of it." He complains of the actions of the commissioned officers and expresses his desire for a quick end to the war.

div.p: I heard from you a day or so ago, so I thought I would answer your kind letter to me throug Miss Mary Smith by the way a particular friend of mine I am glad to heare you are well and getting along finely Mary did not write me much news concerning what was in your letter but wished me to answer it which I am trying to do I am well at present But very tired of the service And would give anything to get out of it it is such a mean Batterry that one can hardly live. The officers are not worth a cent I would as soon have a wooden man over me as any of them I was Gunner on a six pound Gun and I resined the other day and now I am high private, But it is not with us non commissioned officers as it is With the commissioned for when they resign they can quit and go home But we

Cannot But have to stay until the war is over or our three years is out which I hope will soon be. But I cannot tell when it will we have left Corinth and we Came on East further within 50 or 60 miles of Chattanooga where there are some abel troops at present - But I should not wonder if we went thru to Clean them out before long we are now within three miles of Winchester Tenn with a verry wet camping Ground in the woods, We cannot get any papers here at all and cannot tell whether Richmond is taken or not I wish you would send me papers the Grunfield Paper especially for there is always a lot of News in it It is almost as good as a letter of itself, Well tell me how are all the folks in The old town and how are times there at present and how are you getting along and tell me whether Father thinks of coming out west or not we all expect the war will be pretty much over When Richmond is taken Although there is Some few Guerrillas they will soon be

whiped out If I had Knowed as much before I enlisted as I do now I would never come as a private soldier (no not I) But here I am and cannot help it and here I have got to stay unless I get sick, and then only go home on a sick furlough I got a letter from Father some time ago and he said Fostina was not married yet and that Cistopher Clapp was in McClellans Army and Dwight married Widow Cronin, Dan Cronins widow I think Girls are scarce there to marry such a woman as she is why here in the south where we are there 20 Girls to one young man and as pretty us over I saw and rich one the trouble with them is they are Decent and dont like the northern men You need not be surprised to hear of me being married if ever I get out of this army Write me all the news and give my best respects to all the Folks and my friends and tell them the west is the place to make money write soon no more at present
Excuse this writing and mistakes from Your Brother Chas. G Fox
In Care of Capt Geo. T. Cochran,
